dt: {bc}putting an end to or precluding a right of action, debate, or delay
{bc}not providing an opportunity to show cause why one should not comply
{bc}characterized by often imperious or arrogant self-assurance

dt.t: how insolent of late he is become, how proud, how {wi}peremptory{/wi}

dt: {bc}indicative of a peremptory attitude or nature {bc}{sx|haughty||}

pt: {sc}masterful{/sc} {sc}domineering{/sc} {sc}imperious{/sc} {sc}peremptory{/sc} {sc}imperative{/sc} mean tending to impose one's will on others. {sc}masterful{/sc} implies a strong personality and ability to act authoritatively.

pt.t: her {it}masterful{/it} personality soon dominated the movement

pt: {sc}domineering{/sc} suggests an overbearing or arbitrary manner and an obstinate determination to enforce one's will.
{sc}imperious{/sc} implies a commanding nature or manner and often suggests arrogant assurance.

pt.t: an {it}imperious{/it} executive used to getting his own way

pt: {sc}peremptory{/sc} implies an abrupt dictatorial manner coupled with an unwillingness to brook disobedience or dissent.
{sc}imperative{/sc} implies peremptoriness arising more from the urgency of the situation than from an inherent will to dominate.

et: Middle English {it}peremptorie{/it}, from Anglo-French, from Late Latin & Latin; Late Latin {it}peremptorius{/it}, from Latin, destructive, from {it}perimere{/it} to take entirely, destroy, from {it}per-{/it} thoroughly + {it}emere{/it} to take {ma}{mat|redeem|}{/ma}
shortdef: putting an end to or precluding a right of action, debate, or delay; specifically : not providing an opportunity to show cause why one should not comply

dt: {bc}a challenge (as of a juror) made as of right without assigning any cause
